Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Search for Milky Way Black Holes in the Southern Globular Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Globular clusters are dense populations of hundreds of thousands to millions of stars, and were expected to at one point also contain a population of around 1000 stellar-mass black holes. However, theory predicted that as the clusters evolved, these black holes would be ejected from the cluster through gravitationsal interactions with other black holes, leaving only ~1-2% of globular clusters with a stellar-mass black holes. Recent research suggests though, that stellar-mass black holes could be far more common in globular clusters. This project aims to investigate the frequency of black holes in globular clusters using radio observations of Milky Way globular clusters from the Australian Telescope Compact Array (ATCA), and has the potential to increase the number of known black holes in the Milky Way significantly. This work will be done under the supervision of host researcher James Miller-Jones of Curtin University, whose expertise in this subject and access to ATCA are critical to the success of the project.

This project will focus the search for stellar-­mass black holes on cores of the clusters where, through dynamical mass-segregation, these black holes are expected to be. Radio observations are increasingly sensitive to low-­luminosity accretion onto compact objects, which makes the deep ATCA observations ideal for this search. Stellar-­mass black hole candidates will be identified by their flat spectrum radio emission, and followed up with observations at different wavelengths to confirm that candidates are not accreting neutron stars, white dwarfs, or background galaxies. If stellar-­mass black holes are indeed common in globular clusters, this would have significant implications, such as that more accurate study of stellar-­mass black holes could be done, and there would be increased chance of the formation of black hole-­black hole binaries, which would be important sources of gravitational waves. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Globular clusters are dense spherical populations of millions of stars near the outer regions of galaxies. During their lifetime, they were expected to contain a population of about 1000 stellar-mass black holes, which would be ejected from the cluster over time due to violent gravitational interactions with the other black holes in the cluster. This process was long believed to be so efficient that only 1-2% of globular clusters would have a black hole at the present day. However, recent observations have revealed several black hole candidates in globular clusters, at a frequency that suggests black holes are more common in globular clusters than astronomers long believed. And if they are indeed common in globular clusters, this would have significant implications, such as more accurate study of black holes and their physical characteristic could be done, and that there would be a higher chance of black hole-black hole binary formation, providing more gravitational wave sources for the study of gravity. Further, the current confirmed stellar-mass black hole population is relatively small (~30), which statistically limits the study of stellar-mass black holes. If common, globular clusters could be a supreme hunting ground for more stellar-mass black holes, which could increase the current stellar-mass black hole population significantly.

The focus of this project was to investigate the frequency of stellar-mass black holes in southern globular clusters using radio observations from the Australian Telescope Compact Array (ATCA). From the host researcher, James Miller-Jones at Curtin University, the necessary skills were provided to perform the data analysis from ATCA and image several Milky Way globular clusters. Each cluster’s core was searched for radio emission, and candidates were identified by their expected flat radio spectrum. Two new black hole candidates were found, and extensive follow-up at different wavelengths has been and is still being done to determine their exact physical nature and rule out accreting neutron stars, white dwarfs, and background galaxies. This effort is currently ongoing, with continued collaboration between the host’s and fellow’s research groups to investigate these two candidates, as well as new candidates identified since the conclusion of the EAPSI program.
